results.title: acmipark
results.material_description: interactive software, computers, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
acmipark is multiplayer virtual world. Created by selectparks (artists Julian Oliver, Chad Chatterton, and Andrea Blundell), it was designed to extend the physical spaces of the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) at Melbourne’s Federation Square into the realms of virtual space. It was produced using a game engine as its base, and worked up from the real architectural designs produced for Federation Square by Lab Architecture Studio.

Designed as a soundpark, it is a musical instrument which can be played collectively, and, like Federation Square itself, it was envisaged as a kind of public space waiting for a community to define its meaning.

It was conceived as an experiment in the design of a virtual public space. It is an embodiment of the idea that we are moving our public space into the realm of the virtual. By using a model of a real world public space combined with the collaborative possibilities of the soundpark and the kinaesthetic pleasures of moving through a beautiful virtual place, selectparks hoped to build upon traditional concepts of ‘public’ places.

[Source: Helen Stuckey, 2006 https://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1561/1476 last accessed 20/10/2020]

results.title: Fremantle cray fishers
results.brief_description: The departure of the cray fishing boats from Fremantle, Western Australia, in the early morning to the fishing grounds in the deep water. These hard working fishermen work a twelve hour day and are dependent on the weather and the mood of the sea for a good season. After the long day they return to port with their catch.

results.title: No Fixed Address: on tour
results.creator_credit: Media World Productions, Channel 0-28, John Tatoulis and Colin South
results.brief_description: Documentary on the British tour of one of Australia’s leading rock bands, No Fixed Address, a band committed to expressing aspects of their culture and the condition of Aboriginal people through their music. Includes footage of the Brisbane Commonwealth Games protests and also examines British black music.

results.title: A Record of pre-school play
results.creator_credit: Australian Council for Educational Research and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: These children are representative of 100 who commenced primary school in Carlton during 1951. Some children had attended the Lady Gowrie Pre-School Centre, some came from other kindergartens and creches and some had not attended any pre-school centre. The children were assembled for two weeks at the end of 1950 to study their vocabulary and this film was made of their unrehearsed and undirected activities. Photography by Rodney Power.

results.title: Free Climbing
results.brief_description:
Rock climbing is a recreation for some, an obsession for others. “Free Climbing” was filmed at Mt Arapiles and Mt Buffalo and features hair-raising shots as climbers demonstrate safety and technical skills.

Since this work was made (in 1986) there have been significant rediscoveries of indigenous cultural heritage around Mt Arapiles (2019 - 2022). Some of the climbing areas pictured may no longer be accessible due to measures to protect this heritage.

results.title: Heartbreak High’s inclusiveness goes global
results.brief_description: In this video, LGBTIQA+ flags are overlayed on Heartbreak High characters to signal their sexual identities. With over 1M views, it speaks to the popularity of the show but also the importance of representation on TV. Until the 1990s, it was uncommon to find queer characters on screen, so audiences had to do things like search for subtext or create fanfiction. Heartbreak High’s sexually (and culturally) diverse characters reflect contemporary society and the evolution of screen representation, while easy-to-use video and social media tools let fans create shareable content that celebrates diversity and connects like-minded people around the world.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In this video, LGBTIQA+ flags are overlaid on Heartbreak High characters to signal their sexual identities. With over 1M views, it speaks to the popularity of the show but also the importance of representation on TV. Until the 1990s, it was uncommon to find queer characters on screen, so audiences had to do things like search for subtext or create fanfiction. Heartbreak High’s sexually (and culturally) diverse characters reflect contemporary society and the evolution of screen representation, while easy-to-use video and social media tools let fans create shareable content that celebrates diversity and connects like-minded people around the world.
description_for_label: In this video, LGBTIQA+ flags are overlaid on Heartbreak High characters to signal their sexual identities. With over 1M views, it speaks to the show’s popularity but also the importance of screen representation. Until the 1990s, queer screen characters were uncommon, so audiences had to search for subtext or create fanfiction. Heartbreak High’s sexually (and culturally) diverse characters reflect our society and the evolution of screen representation, while easy-to-use video tools let fans create shareable content that celebrates diversity and strengthens community.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Tractor goth girl
results.brief_description: TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.
description_for_label: TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.

results.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.credit_line:
Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.brief_description: During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life.

constellations_primary.name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films
constellations_primary.description: Analects of Kung Phu work is a philosophical guide to life via martial arts films, drawing on his interest in Vietnamese and Chinese folklore, which inspires many of the films featured in this Constellation.

results.title_for_label: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like Drunken Master (1978) and Avatar the Last Airbender (2005–08), Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s Dao De Jing, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales.

Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

Read more

More than 200 kung fu films later, Jason Phu had his own movie to make by Kerrie O’Brien

My parents met at the fish market by Jason Phu in The Lifted Brow

Interview #34 — Jason Phu by Sophia Cai in Liminal

Storytelling with Jason Phu by Sabina McKenna in Acclaim

Who is Jason Phu? by Jane Albert in Broadsheet

I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s “Dao De Jing”, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales. results.title: The Gods of Tiny Things
results.credit_line:
Deborah Kelly

Two-channel digital animation, colour, sound

ACMI Collection

Collage figures: Joanne Albany, Alana Ambados, Kate Andrews, Justin Ashworth, Kathryn Bird, Karen Golland, Amanda Holt, Deborah Kelly, Kath Lim, Lex Lindsay, Megan Rushton, Rie Tamaoke, Anna Tregloan
results.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

constellations_primary.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_primary.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life.” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. Kelly’s moving image artworks have been shown around the world, in galleries, cinemas and projected onto rock formations, buildings and clouds.
description_for_label: The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life.
